posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
"I go in big wood door.  People in thar wear rags and then say I now monk like them.  I see knife wut look like to cut chicken head but monk say it weapon for battle.  These very strange folk am thinking.  They show me bed to sleep.  When I wake up, just rags on bed and my armor gone.  Now wut I do?"
This poor fellow has lost more than his armor.  He can't make heads-or-tails of his role anymore. The more he tries to fit in, the more confusing it gets until his life makes no sense at all anymore.  It was so much easier running around the battlefield swinging his axe. I recommend steering clear of this guy now.  He's unstable thanks to some poor choices. He's still has orcish blood running through his veins and now, armed with two odd-looking blades, has only one instinct left... kill anything that comes within arm's reach.  As the bloke would say if he were here:  "Blud is gud!"  And so it goes...

Since there is no way for me to test this toon on a server (they all enforce AD&D rules), I've begun testing via trainer vs. my own designed encounters.  Let's just say at this point, it's interesting.  It's ridiculously easy to taunt a paralyzed adversary.

For those of you missing the joke, this is my own personal editorial on how to best misuse an alignment manager.  It gave me a chuckle after sweating my butt off today so I figured to share this combo that only now exists in the universe of build minutia and our minds.

posts.content: Other alignment-defying builds with great potential would be Monk / Bard / X and Paladin / Bard / X.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:
Other alignment-defying builds with great potential would be Monk / Bard / X and Paladin / Bard / X.
Agreed. I've often dreamed the concept of a bardic monk and woke up cursing the realities of the game's alignment mechanics.  But what can we do?  Either play Dungeons and Dragons as designed or look for a game that only resembles it with rules more suited to our presonal bias.
